conclusion: The graph shows velocity (v) vs. time (t). The velocity is measured in m·s⁻¹, and time is measured in seconds. The positive direction on the vertical axis represents the defined positive direction of motion.
At t = 2s, the velocity is 0 m·s⁻¹.
Between t = 2s and t = 3s, the velocity decreases linearly to -2 m·s⁻¹.
At t = 3s, the velocity is -2 m·s⁻¹.

premise: When the velocity is negative, it means the particle is moving in the direction opposite to the defined positive direction.
conclusion: Since the velocity during this time interval is negative (specifically between 0 and -2 m·s⁻¹), the particle is moving in the negative direction.

premise: Displacement is the area under the v-t curve.
conclusion: From t = 2s to t = 3s, this area is negative (a triangular region below the x-axis). Negative displacement confirms motion in the negative direction.

premise: The velocity during this interval is negative.
conclusion: From 2 to 3 seconds, the particle is moving in the direction opposite to the defined positive direction.
